bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, January 27, 1944

div1.p: Hench promises to send Truby additional extracts from some of Reed's letters. Hench offers his opinion on people who are not fully backing the war effort.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, January 27, 1944
div1.opener:
2A
T
ARMY AND NAVY GENERAL HOSPITAL
OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OF MEDICAL SERVICE
27 January 1944
HOT SPRINGS NATIONAL PARK, ARKANSAS
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I received the cover of the note book three or four days before receiv-
ing the letter and was frankly puzzled why you had sent it. I was afraid you
had sent it with something else and that the letter had fallen out of the en-
velope. I am glad to have it as it will help me know what I am looking for;
however, Carroll described a small pocket note book. I certainly hope that
some day I will be successful and may be able to see Carroll's journal.

While I was in Washington I loaned Carroll your book. He is a very
taciturn fellow and is more inclined not to like something than to like it;
nevertheless, he said he liked your book very much although there were a few
things he could not agree with. He was not specific enough in the latter.

I am glad that you like the extracts from the Walter Reed letter; I
will see if I can find other extracts. As soon as I can have the photographs
of the yellow fever huts made I will send you one. I have not heard anything
from anyone in Cuba. I don't even know that they have seen your books. I
am about to receive the twenty-five or thirty copies that I ordered in Decem-
ber.

I shall be anxious to hear whether you have been able to make contact
with Lampson. There are many statements in his book that need carrying out. following up.
He had much specific information that no one else seems to have and I suspect
that he made it up.

Congratulations on your nice summary.recovery. Your hand writing doesn't seem,
to me, to be much different from your old hand writing. Be sure to take care
of yourself so that that will not happen again.

I think I am going to like it here very much. So far I am not over im-
pressed with the town. It irritates me incessantly to see hundreds of people
crowding in here for the racing season, to see them lounging around the hotels
talking about horses and money while the war is going on. These damn fools
don't seem to realize that a war is going on. Why they will allow the racing
season to continue here when it has been so difficult for medical men to have
medical meetings I do not see. One unhappy result is that we medical officers
have to compete for rooms at the very highest prices; no consideration whatever
is given to us and it does not give one a feeling of hospitality.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, PHILIP S. HENCH
Lt. Colonel, M.C. FOR VICTORY
BUY
UNITED
STATES
WAR
BONDS
AND
STAMPS
